awd_titl_txt: Conference: Genomic Consequences of Meiotic Drive Workshop
awd_abstract_narration:
The “Genomic Consequences of Meiotic Drive” Workshop will be held in Arolla, Switzerland in June 2023 and involve 20-30 attendees. Meiotic drive is a phenomenon that occurs across most eukaryotic groups of organisms (mammals, plants, insects, fungi, nematodes). Instead of gametogenesis resulting in equal representation in the gametes, gametogenesis in a meiotic drive system results in mostly one of the two homologous chromosomes. Thus, meiotic drive loci cheat normal Mendelian segregation which aids their spread through populations. Meiotic drive has several potential evolutionary consequences, but it also leaves a profound signature on the genomes of species with drivers. The enormous amount of genomic data now available for meiotic drive system will facilitate a synthetic review of the genomic consequences of meiotic drive. 

Our approach is to bring researchers together to present their work on genomic consequences of meiotic drive, then brainstorm and draft a review article that synthesizes the field. This model follows two prior reviews on different aspects of meiotic drive published in 2016 and 2020. Our work will provide a comprehensive overview of the field for both specialists in meiotic drive and those who need to consider meiotic drive as a tangent to their own research questions. This work will be impactful to the genetics/genomics community as a whole. The workshop is also designed to elevate the research of newcomers to this field. Our attendee list is purposefully enriched for early career researchers and researchers from diverse backgrounds. The format of the workshop allows for easy interaction between researchers from all levels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Meiotic drive is a common phenomenon across plants, animals and fungi. It occurs when a gene (or complex of genes) biases its own transmission in the next generation above the expectations set out by Mendel. Over the past 20 years, the impact of meiotic drive on host genomes has been elucidated in many systems. The goal of this award was to hold a conference where progress was synthesized, discussing the progress in the field, then writing a synthetic review of the field. 

The workshop on the genomic consequences of drive was held June 13 – June 17, 2023 in Arolla, Switzerland. In attendance were 24 participants: 6 graduate students, 1 undergraduate technician, 3 postdoctoral researchers, and 13 faculty members. The meeting was balanced in its representation of training stage (10/24 participants in a training phase), gender (14/24 participants were women), and model organisms/systems (5 different Drosophila species/systems, maize, stalk-eyed flies, 4 fungi, monkeyflowers, mice, Caenorhabditis worms, and fish). One additional graduate student was invited but had to cancel at the last minute due to problems with her passport. We had a successful meeting and stuck close to our proposed schedule, goals, and budget. Below we report on workshop outcomes and our progress towards meeting the short- and long-term goals.

Workshop goals and progress:

The overarching goal of this workshop was to gather current and future leaders in the meiotic drive field to synthesize insights from recent evolutionary and functional genomics studies and to develop future research priorities. 

Workshop outcome 1– Exchange ideas and networking: One major goal of the workshop was to create a community and provide networking opportunities for trainees by engaging in discussion, presentations, leading workshop discussions, and writing. Our small workshop gathered researchers studying meiotic drive in plants, animals, and fungi using diverse approaches from molecular genetics, evolutionary genomics, computational biology, ecology, and mathematical modeling. Our participants range from undergraduate technicians to full professors and represented labs from five continents. The workshop participants shared new insights from both well-established and newly-discovered meiotic drive systems that highlight the diversity of mechanisms, the emerging common themes, and the far-reaching effects drive has on shaping genome evolution. The trainees were outstanding. They gave excellent presentations, participated in discussions, emerged as leaders around several discussion topics, and wrote content for the review (below). 

 

Workshop outcome 2– Write a collaborative review: Another major goal we had for this workshop was to write a collaborative critical review/perspective piece synthesizing insights across systems and mapping out future prospects in the field. Our two previous meetings each produced highly cited reviews (Lindholm et al. 2016; Price et al. 2020). All workshop participants then brainstormed the organization of the review and broke into small groups to begin drafting content. The first draft of the review is nearly complete. It discusses an overview of drive systems and some exemplars (e.g., drive supergenes vs. single genes; segregating/balanced vs. fixed drivers), parallel features of drive systems (e.g., at the level of genes and chromosomes) and genomic consequences of drive including host-drive dynamics and genomic signatures of conflict. The review will include boxes that connect to our intended long term impacts to map future research goals for the research community to understand the impact of meiotic drive systems on genome and species evolution. We also link new genomic insights to relevant parameters for synthetic drive systems: molecular mechanisms, mutation & genetic variation, population structure, population genetics models of drive/suppression dynamics, and factors mediating the evolution of suppression/resistance. We intend to submit this review to the journal, Molecular Biology and Evolution, in the fall of 2024.
